bioghist.p: James Hanley (1901-1985) was a British novelist. Born in Dublin, he went to sea at a young age, joining the Canadian Expeditionary Forces during World War I. His early writing focused on the lives of men who work on the sea. His novels were critically acclaimed, but most of them did not sell very well. Frank Harrington was a book collector who collected Hanley's works and corresponded extensively with the author.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence and manuscripts of James Hanley, collected by Frank Harrington. Many of the letters are between Hanley and Harrington, written primarily in the 1970s and 1980s. This correspondence relates to the publication of Hanley's works, his life in Great Britain, his family, and the authors and poets that he enjoys reading. There is additional correspondence between Hanley and Sven Tackmark about the publication of Hanley's works and production of a play in Scandinavia, and correspondence from Harrington about his collection of Hanley's works as well as of other writers. The collection also includes reviews of Hanley's books, photographs, a biographical essay on Hanley, and clippings.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
